ABOUT ME


PhD Candidate | Econ | University of Pittsburgh

My work typically involves individual-level panel data, aiming at questions about individuals in groups, using both administrative data and experimental methods.

My research agenda lives in the sub-fields of political economy, urban, and behavioral economics, how changing economic conditions interact with the democratic process, exploiting a geocoded administrative panel of voters, their neighborhoods, and their turnout decisions.

I enjoy communicating both simple and complex concepts clearly and have a tendency to stray from under the street lamp.


Research



Current

Herding to the Polls

tl;dr. Voters condition their turnout decision on the political preferences of their neighbors.


R & R at JEEA

Testing Models of Strategic Uncertainty:
Equilibrium Selection in Repeated Games

(with Alistair Wilson and Emanuel Vespa)

tl;dr.


Current

The Small Sort

tl;dr. Voters have a preference for living near politically aligned neighbors.
